column8: Notes

Starting a company needs to be unpacked a bit. (1) What prompted them to start a company? (2) Have they done some level of (a) market validation/customer development (b) product validation at this point? (3) Assumption that starting a company = getting EIN; (4) What other actions do they need to take in order to become a company?
Under what context would they see the ad? What do we want them to do with the ads? What are the conversion metrics?

column2: Follow NSF SBIR on social media
column8: How would your target audience learn about NSF SBIR at this stage? Solely through ads?
(1) There are no events or other time-based content on the site. (Even the submission deadlines tend to be buried.) (2) No system for managing contacts

column3: VC Summit and similar investor events
Local Transfer of Technology (ToT) or Development of Technology Transfer office
Funding webinars (e.g., CIT.org — Center for Innovation Technology: http://www.cit.org/service-lines/cit-entrepreneur-webinars/ )

column8: Unable to segment subscribers or collect any data-based insight. Only collects email addresses. Low frequency broadcast channel. Primary channel for notifying new solicitation/application deadline.

column2: Research and figure out other awardees
column8: Users did not find the search listings or the available data on the companies very helpful.

column3: Reaching out to network to see if they know NSF SBIR
Emails (PD contact info obtained from website)
column8: Some email different PDs and get different answers from each. 10-12% of executive summaries fall through the cracks and are left unanswered. (This is sensitive; a known problem)

column3: Program Director receives an unsolicited email; prompts them for a summary.

column8: Each solicitation only active ~60 days each year.

column3: NSF SBIR website (Discover through site, email signature, social media, listserv)
column8: NSF SBIR is not allowed to conduct these until the solicitation has been posted. Registration captures email.
FAQs need to undergo legal review

column2: Apply for a DUNS number (requires EIN tax number)
column8: (1) Takes 30 days for a free DUNS number or 5 days for a $50 fee.
(1) How long does this process take if you’re starting from scratch?

column2: Register firm with SBIR.gov (requires EIN, DUNS)
column8: (1) May take 2-6 weeks turnaround.

column2: Register firm with NSF Fastlane (requires EIN, DUNS)
column8: (1) Takes 1-2 days turnaround. (2) Need to identify Principal Investigator (PI)

column2: Begin to gather letters of support.
column6: Third-party contacts provide letters of support in writing.
column8: (1) Is there a template or a set of guidelines for this? (2) How is this currently submitted? (3) Can they submit soft copies? (4) Do the letters need to be notarized? I.e., how do you verify/authenticate?

Info includes: Outline of proposal (structured); Financials / Budget (structured); Refer to  Department of Labor/Bureau of Labor Statistics for salary ranges; Project Summary (structured); Personnel (structured); Resumes / CVs (unstructured); Cover Sheet (structured); Letters of Support (unstructured); Business Model (unstructured); Commercialization history / SBA Certification form (unstructured)
(This is a known pain point as the applicant has to create another account to submit as a research administrator. Applications wind up being disqualified because they are deemed incomplete.)
(1) Help Desk receives hundreds of calls during peak period

column4: Applicant has to proactively log in to check status. Receives no notification.
column6: NSF screens proposals. Proposals that do not meet basic specifications are returned without review (RWR)
column8: Usually takes about 1 week. Reasons for RWR: (1) Projects which were submitted late (2) Projects with project descriptions > 15 pages (if the extra pages have no significant content, we will usually let them go to panel, but if it looks like it’s too much to have put on 15 pages, they will be returned) (3) Projects asking for significantly more than $225,000 (4) Some projects which are completely missing a commercial discussion will get flagged by the staff and returned.

column4: Applicant has to proactively log in to check status. Receives no notification.
column5: FastLane sends an email that sounds like an acceptance, but it isn’t.

column4: Applicant has to proactively log in to check status. Receives no notification.
Applicant has to proactively log in to check status. Receives no notification.

column6: Some applicants may get requests for additional information. Long lead-time items not already completed (e.g. human or animal subjects approvals, cooperative research agreements, etc.) should be expedited.

column2: PI receives recommend or reject email.
column5: PI notified by email / status update whether proposal is recommended or rejected. Managed via e-jacket.
column8: Decisions are final. No protests — but are allowed to submit another Phase I proposal. (1) Do applicants receive additional feedback on why they were rejected?

column4: Applicant has to proactively log in to check status. Receives no notification.
column5: Proposals that have been recommended undergo multiple reviews from PD to Division Director, then 30 days to financial office. Managed via e-jacket.
Award letter sent to PI via e-jacket.

column2: Register for Awards Cash Management System.

column4: Ask questions about drawing down funds.
column8: 20% of the money is withheld until the very end of the Phase I period upon receipt of the final report.

column2: Awardees attend Phase I grantee workshop.
Provide updates via program director office hours, monthly phone calls, and/or written reports
At the end of the Phase I period, submit final report.
column4: Log in and submit through Research.gov: https://identity.research.gov/sso/UI/Login

column2: Customer able to access remaining funding
